articles.author: Sazardev
articles.description:
Surviving Extreme Programming: A Developer's Wild Ride


Have you ever wanted to strap your coding practices to a rocket and send them to the moon? That is what Extreme Programming (XP) does to traditional software development. As a developer who has been through the XP wringer, I am here to tell you it is both terrifying and exhilarating - like riding a rollercoaster built by the same people who review your pull requests.
Extreme Programming is like regular programming, but after it's chugged five espressos. It takes good engineering practices and cranks them up to eleven.
Think of it this way: If traditional development is like carefully planning a road trip with maps and hotel reservations, XP is more like deciding to drive cross-country with only a compass, a full tank of gas, and the ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Surviving Extreme Programming: A Developer's Wild Ride

articles.author: Debbie O'Brien
articles.description:
Debugging failing tests can be time-consuming and frustrating‚Äîespecially when error messages are long or snapshot diffs are difficult to interpret. With the latest AI-powered tools in Playwright, resolving test failures has become significantly faster and more intuitive.
Consider a basic Playwright test that uses snapshot testing to verify that the content inside getByRole('main') matches a previously stored snapshot. The snapshot might contain two distinct headings, for example.
If the heading level in the application is changed‚Äîfrom <h1> to <h2>‚Äîthe test fails, as expected, due to a mismatch with the stored snapshot. Traditionally, resolving this would involve reading the stack trace, analyzing the diff, and manually updating the test or snapshot.
Playwright‚Äôs AI integration streamlines ‚Ä¶
articles.title: Debugging Playwright Tests with AI: A Smarter, Faster Workflow

articles.author: 1suleyman
articles.description:
Hey everyone üëã
If you're jumping into software development, especially on a team, you've probably heard about Git and GitHub. It can feel a bit overwhelming at first, with all the talk of branches, commits, and pull requests. But really, it's just a structured way for teams to build awesome software together without stepping on each other's toes.
Let me break down "The GitHub Flow" ‚Äî the common, effective workflow for managing your code with Git and GitHub ‚Äî in a way that I wish someone had explained to me early on üëá
üß∏ Think of It Like Building with LEGOs (on a Team)
The "main" branch is like the complete, stable castle everyone agrees on. You don't want someone randomly ripping out a wall from the main castle while others are still playing with it, right?
The GitHub Flow is the set of ‚Ä¶
articles.title: üöÄ Understanding The GitHub Flow: Your Blueprint for Collaborative Coding

articles.author: Jonathan Rocha
articles.description:
Como verificar e gerenciar servi√ßos no Linux (Red Hat)


Se voc√™ trabalha com servidores Linux, em especial Red Hat ou semelhantes como CentOS ou Rocky Linux, √© essencial saber lidar com servi√ßos em execu√ß√£o. Preparei comandos simples para identificar servi√ßos ativos, liberar portas desnecess√°rias e evitar problemas de seguran√ßa.
üìå Verificando servi√ßos ativos


No Linux com¬†systemd, usamos o comando¬†systemctl:
Listar todos os servi√ßos ativos:





systemctl list-units --type=service

Ver status de um servi√ßo espec√≠fico (ex: Apache, MySQL):





systemctl status mysqld.service


Ver servi√ßos configurados para iniciar no boot:





systemctl list-unit-files --type=service

üîç Verificando servi√ßos escutando em portas de rede


Para identificar portas abertas, use o comando¬†ss¬†(substituto do¬†netstat):
Ver portas abertas:





ss -tuln

Ver processos escutando em cada porta:





ss -tulnp

Alternativa com¬†netstat¬†(se instalado):





netstat -tulnp


üõë Parar e desabilitar servi√ßos n√£o utilizados


Servi√ßos desnecess√°rios consomem recursos. Para desativ√°-los:
systemctl stop nome-do-servi√ßo
systemctl disable nome-do-servi√ßo

Exemplo: Parando o Mysql





systemctl stop mysqld.service
systemctl disable mysqld.service


‚öôÔ∏è Automatizando verifica√ß√µes


Crie um script em Bash para agilizar verifica√ß√µes:
#!/bin/bashecho "Servi√ßos ativos:"
systemctl list-units --type=service

echo "Portas escutando:"
ss -tulnp

Dica:
Agende com¬†cron¬†ou execute manualmente.
üìå Notas:



Use¬†sudo¬†se necess√°rio para comandos privilegiados.
articles.title: Gerenciando Servi√ßos Linux

articles.author: Arthur Groupp
articles.description:
Debouncing is a foundational technique in front-end development, especially when working with high-frequency events like user input. It helps control the rate of function calls, ensuring that performance-intensive operations‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääsuch as server requests‚Ää‚Äî‚Äädon‚Äôt trigger excessively as users interact with the UI. A classic example is a search bar: as the user types, the application waits until they‚Äôve paused before sending a request to fetch matching results. Another familiar case is an autocomplete panel, where each keystroke could theoretically initiate a query‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääbut shouldn‚Äôt.
In Angular applications, especially those using the new reactive primitives introduced with Signals, developers often ask: ‚ÄúHow do I debounce a signal?‚Äù At first glance, this might seem like a natural extension of reac‚Ä¶
articles.title: Effective Debouncing in Angular: Keep Signals Pure

A proposta deste texto, ent√£o, √© "escovar bits" sobre alguns conceitos de sistemas operacionais, partindo da seguinte pergunta: rodar um fork bomb em uma m√°quina virtual pode comprometer os recursos da m√°quina hospedeira? E no caso de estarmos usando um cont√™iner Docker?
Para alguns, a resposta √† pergunta acima pode parecer √≥bvia. Para outros, nem tanto. H√° ainda um terceiro grupo que talvez se pergunte: o que √© um fork bomb?
Fork bomb √© uma f‚Ä¶
articles.title: Virtualiza√ß√£o, processos e fork bomb

articles.author: Lourdes Suello
articles.description:
"Prop drilling" is a term in React (and other component-based UI frameworks) that describes the act of passing data down through multiple layers of nested components, even if the intermediate components don't actually need or use that data. They simply serve as conduits to pass the data further down the component tree until it reaches the component that actually needs it.
Here's a breakdown of what it is, why it's a problem, and common solutions:
What it is:
App
  ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ParentComponent
  ‚îÇ     ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ ChildComponent
  ‚îÇ     ‚îÇ     ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ GrandchildComponent
  ‚îÇ     ‚îÇ           ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ DeeplyNestedComponent (needs 'userData')

If App has some userData that only DeeplyNestedComponent needs, you would have to pass userData as a prop from:
App to ParentComponent
ParentComponent to ChildComponent
ChildCompon‚Ä¶
articles.title: What is Prop Drilling

articles.author: Jacob
articles.description:
IOMete is a powerful, cloud-independent data platform built on Apache Spark, designed to enable scalable data processing and analytics. This guide walks you through the process of setting up IOMete on a Kubernetes cluster, covering the installation of prerequisites, configuration of storage and database components, and deployment of the IOMete data plane. By the end, you‚Äôll have a fully functional IOMete environment ready for data workloads.
Before diving into the installation, ensure you have the following:
A Kubernetes cluster (version 1.21 or higher recommended).
kubectl configured to interact with your cluster.
Helm (version 3.x) installed for managing chart deployments.
yq (a YAML processor) installed for modifying configuration files.
aws-cli installed for interacting with MinIO (con‚Ä¶
articles.title: Setting Up IOMete: A Cloud-Independent Data Platform Based on Spark
